Photovoltaic systems, also known as solar cell systems, convert sunlight into electricity by using solar panels to generate electrical current. Solar panels consist of interconnected solar cells, which are small units that convert sunlight into electrical energy. Each solar cell receives several light particles, which cause it to emit an electrical current. The electrical current is then collected and converted into electricity.

Thermal solar systems, on the other hand, generate heat by using solar panels to heat up water, which is then used to produce electricity or steam. The solar panels are connected to a heat exchanger, which absorbs the heat from the sun and releases it into the water, causing it to heat up and generate electricity or steam.

In terms of applications and benefits, both types of solar energy systems have their distinct advantages. Photovoltaic systems are more energy efficient than traditional coal-fired power plants, and they have a lower carbon footprint. They can be installed in areas where electricity is in high demand, such as remote regions or off-grid living. Thermal solar systems, on the other hand, are more effective in generating electricity or steam in cooler climates or where electricity demand is high. They can also be used to provide heat to homes or businesses, which can save money in the long run.

* The largest solar energy system in the world, the Patchi Solar Farm, is located in California, USA. It is capable of generating enough electricity to power approximately 160,000 homes and businesses in the area.

* The largest solar farm in Europe, the solar farm in Nackens, Norway, is capable of generating enough electricity to power approximately 6,000 homes and businesses in the area.
